column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity has been recalculated according to TPI methodology. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI assumes that the company’s passenger activity grows according to the passenger aviation activity growth rate projected in the IEA’s 2020 Energy Technology Perspective (ETP) and that its freight activity grows according to ICAO post-COVID projections. TPI also assumes that the company’s well-to-wake emissions intensity reduction target could be applied to Scope 1 jet fuel emissions proportionately. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tCO2e/tonnes agricultural input)
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions and emissions intensity. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that the used agricultural inputs used by the company grow according to the global agricultural input production forecasts from several Integrated Assessment Models under a Business-as-Usual scenario. Also, the company does not explicitly disclose whether agriculture-driven GHGs emissions attributable to the effect of Land Use and Land Use Change are included in its reported Scope 3 - Category 1 emissions. TPI assumes that these are included. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (metric tonnes of CO2 per MWh electricity generation)
column19:
The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI assumes that the company's electricity generation grows according to the national or regional electricity generation growth rate projected in the IEA's 2020 World Energy Outlook's Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS).

The company's target applies to Scope 1 and 2 emissions, which normally would not be accepted in TPI's electricity methodology because targets must be stated explicitly as referring to Scope 1 emissions from electricity generation. However, Algonquin Power & Utilities has made explicit that it will meet its target by closing a coal facility. We therefore assume that effectively their target will be applied to the emissions from electricity generation. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity has been recalculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set a net target for 2050, which includes offsets. In the aviation sector, TPI can only use such targets if the percentage of the target that will be met using offsets is disclosed by the company. Using a visualisation published by the company, TPI estimated an implicit emissions intensity target for the company by excluding company reliance on offsets. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity has been recalculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set a net target for 2050, which includes offsets. In the aviation sector, TPI can only use such targets if the percentage of the target that will be met using offsets is disclosed by the company. Using a visualisation published by the company, TPI estimated an implicit absolute gross emissions target for the company. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI assumes that the company’s passenger activity grows according to the passenger aviation activity growth rate projected in the IEA’s 2020 Energy Technology Perspective (ETP) and that its freight activity grows according to ICAO projections.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company's target covers only Scope 1 and 2 emissions. The Scope 3 emissions intensity (Categories 10 and 11), which is not covered by the target, is assumed to remain constant from the latest year of disclosure. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector.  When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company has one or more intermediate targets that cover only Scope 1 and 2 emissions, while its long-term target covers Scope 3 emissions. The emissions intensity for Scope 3 is linearly interpolated between the latest year of disclosure and the target year of the target that covers Scope 3. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonnes of CO2 per tonne of steel)
column19:
Arcelor Mittal has set targets to reduce its emissions intensity. For this company, TPI has assumed that:
● The ratio of Scope 1 and 2 emissions to total emissions in the scope of the company’s targets in the base year is the same as applied between 2015 and 2017.
● Scope 1 and 2 emissions are reduced in proportion to the company’s targets, which apply to a broader scope of emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonnes of CO2 per tonne of steel)
Carbon intensity (tCO2e/tonnes agricultural input)
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that the used agricultural inputs used by the company grow according to the global agricultural input production forecasts from several Integrated Assessment Models under a Business-as-Usual scenario. Also, the company does not explicitly disclose whether agriculture-driven GHGs emissions attributable to the effect of Land Use and Land Use Change are included in its reported Scope 3 - Category 1 emissions. TPI assumes that these are included. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: The company has not disclosed quantitative targets to reduce its emissions, which TPI can use to estimate future carbon performance. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool.  When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company has one or more intermediate targets that cover only Scope 1 and 2 emissions, while its long-term target covers Scope 3 emissions. The emissions intensity for Scope 3 is linearly interpolated between the latest year of disclosure and the target year of the target that covers Scope 3.

Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: TPI has not made any further assumptions in order to project this company’s Carbon Performance. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that the company’s passenger activity grows according to the passenger aviation activity growth rate projected in the IEA’s 2020 Energy Technology Perspective (ETP) and that its freight activity grows according to ICAO projections. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity recalculated according to TPI methodology is significantly different from the intensities disclosed by the company and we could not use the estimated figures with confidence to show the company’s emissions intensity pathway. The company has set targets to reduce its net emissions, but they could not be included in this assessment as it was not possible to make them consistent with TPI’s methodology (which excludes offsets in the aviation sector). When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (metric tonnes of CO2 per MWh electricity generation)
column19: TPI generally assesses companies based on the emissions intensity of their owned generation. However, in the case of Chubu and TEPCO, taking the emissions intensity of sold electricity (i.e. power sales) provides a more representative assessment of these two companies’ transition risk, given that it includes the emissions of JERA, an electricity utility that TEPCO and Chubu jointly own.  When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (metric tonnes of CO2 per MWh electricity generation)
column19: TPI generally assesses companies based on the emissions intensity of their owned generation. However, in the case of Chubu and TEPCO, taking the emissions intensity of sold electricity (i.e. power sales) provides a more representative assessment of these two companies' transition risk, given that it includes the emissions of JERA, an electricity utility that TEPCO and Chubu jointly own. Note that the pathway above includes JERA's emissions and that a pathway for Chubu's emissions intensity excluding JERA would be at 0.012 tCO2/MWh in 2020. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonnes of CO2 per tonne of cementitious product)
column19: TPI has made several assumptions in order to calculate this company’s emissions pathway. Notably, TPI assumes that this company's cement equivalent production equals the company's cementitious material production. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from cement production and compare the company's cement-specific pathway to TPI's cement-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonnes of CO2 per tonne of pulp, paper and paperboard)
Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: The company has not disclosed quantitative targets to reduce its emissions, which TPI can use to estimate future carbon performance. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Emissions intensity (gCO2e / MJ)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from oil & gas production and compare the company's oil & gas pathway to TPI's oil & gas benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company.

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: The company has set a target to reduce its emissions intensity. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

The company's target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use and/or processing of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure.

column18: Carbon intensity (metric tonnes of CO2 per MWh electricity generation)
column19:
Fortis has set a target to reduce its absolute emissions.TPI has adjusted this target by assuming that future electricity generation grows at the same rate as the IEA's "Gross electricity generation" projections for the region in which the company operates using the ETP (2017) Reference Technology Scenario. TPI also assumes that: 
● Emissions from electricity production will reduce in-line with a broader emissions target 
● Emissions revelent to the TPI that are not covered by the target are assumed to be unchanged from the target base year in absolute or intensity terms
● The historic ratio of emissions from electricity production to the emission metric used in the target applies in the future

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: TPI assumes that the company’s 2045 net zero target, will specifically apply to the use of sold product emissions intensity of new passenger vehicles sold by the company in 2045. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. This assessment includes the company's marketing business; we assume that this consists of physical trading and that the company's net zero target does not apply to its marketing business. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector.  When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity has been recalculated according to TPI methodology. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI assumes that the company’s passenger activity grows according to the passenger aviation activity growth rate projected in the IEA’s 2020 Energy Technology Perspective (ETP) and that its freight activity grows according to ICAO post-COVID projections. TPI also assumes that the company’s well-to-wake emissions intensity reduction target could be applied to Scope 1 jet fuel emissions proportionately.  When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: TPI has not made any further assumptions in order to project this company’s Carbon Performance. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Emissions intensity (gCO2e / MJ)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘National Pledges’ scenario. The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its emissions intensity and have described the measures that will be used to achieve these targets. As offsets or market-based measures are not included in the set of measures used to meet these targets, we assume that offsets are not included in the company’s targets and therefore incorporate them into our assessment.  The company’s targets aim to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI assumes that the company’s passenger activity grows according to the passenger aviation activity growth rate projected in the IEA’s 2020 Energy Technology Perspective (ETP) and that its freight activity grows according to ICAO projections. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity has been recalculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set a net target for 2040, which includes offsets. In the aviation sector, TPI can only use such targets if the percentage of the target that will be met using offsets is disclosed by the company. Using a visualisation published by the company, TPI estimated an implicit emissions intensity target for the company by excluding company reliance on offsets. TPI assumes that the company’s passenger activity grows according to the passenger aviation activity growth rate projected in the IEA’s 2020 Energy Technology Perspective (ETP) and that its freight activity grows according to ICAO projections. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity has been recalculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets for 2035, 2040 and 2050 to reduce its emissions intensity, but only the 2040 target could not be included in this assessment as it was not possible to make them consistent with TPI’s methodology (which excludes offsets in the aviation sector). When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. column18: Carbon intensity (gCO2 / RTK)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity and target using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI’s methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity has been recalculated according to TPI methodology. It is assumed that for the years 2014 to 2016, GHG emissions from jet fuel as a proportion of total Scope 1 GHG emissions are the same as that for 2018. It is also assumed that freight operations are negligible. TPI assumes from the information disclosed that the company has adopted the industry target to improve fuel efficiency by an average of 1.5% per year between 2009 and 2020.

column18: Carbon intensity (metric tonnes of CO2 per MWh electricity generation)
column19:
The company has set a target to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI assumes that the company’s electricity generation grows according to the national or regional electricity generation growth rate projected in the IEA’s 2020 World Energy Outlook’s Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS).
Furthermore, TPI assumes that the net zero vision constitutes a commitment. However, we cannot guarantee this view will be upheld in future assessments of the company if the ambiguity in public disclosures persists.   When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: The company has set intermediate targets to reduce its absolute emissions that could not be included in this assessment as the targets could not be made consistent with TPI’s methodology for the auto manufacturing sector. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its emissions intensity. TPI’s benchmarks harmonize emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company's targets are understood to cover only Scope 1 and 2 emissions. The Scope 3 emissions intensity (Categories 10 and 11), which is not covered by the target, is assumed to remain constant from the latest year of disclosure. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonnes of CO2 per tonne of cementitious product)
column19: The company has not disclosed sufficient current emissions data. Even though the company disclosed quantitative targets to reduce its emissions, TPI is unable to estimate the future Carbon Performance of the company due to the lack of historical data. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from cement production and compare the company's cement-specific pathway to TPI's cement-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

Carbon intensity (tCO2e/tonnes agricultural input)
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that the used agricultural inputs used by the company grow according to the global agricultural input production forecasts from several Integrated Assessment Models under a Business-as-Usual scenario. Also, the company does not explicitly disclose whether agriculture-driven GHGs emissions attributable to the effect of Land Use and Land Use Change are included in its reported Scope 3 - Category 1 emissions. TPI assumes that these are included. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Emissions intensity (gCO2e / MJ)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set a target to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. The company has set an additional target to reduce its emissions intensity which could not be included in this assessment as it was not possible to make it consistent with TPI’s methodology.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonnes of CO2 per tonne of pulp, paper and paperboard)
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that the company’ s pulp, paper and paperboard production grows according to the global growth rate projected in the IEA’ s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. TPI also assumes that the emissions intensity of the pulp and paper business in Japan is representative of the company’s carbon performance, since Japanese production accounts for over 82% of the company’s global paper production. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column19:

- The company’s future pulp, paper and paperboard production grows at the same rate as IEA projections.

Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: TPI has not made any further assumptions in order to project this company’s Carbon Performance. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (metric tonnes of CO2 per MWh electricity generation)
column19: The company discloses an emissions intensity using an activity measure and/or emissions figure that is inconsistent with TPI's methodology for this sector. The carbon intensity has been recalculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensities, TPI assumes that the company’s electricity generation grows according to the national or regional electricity generation growth rate projected in the IEA’s 2020 World Energy Outlook’s Stated Policies Scenario (STEPS). Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from electricity generation and compare the company's electricity-specific pathway to TPI's electricity-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company.

column18: Emissions intensity (gCO2e / MJ)
column19:
The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company's 2016 carbon intensity has been calculated by TPI using the company's Scope 3 category 3 2017 emissions figure.
The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. The company’s 2022 target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. The company has set further targets to reduce its emissions intensity, but they could not be included in this assessment as it was not possible to make them consistent with TPI’s methodology. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: TPI has assumed that both tank-to-wheel and well-to-tank emissions fall by equal proportions in meeting the company’s well-to-wheel target. TPI has also assumed that the average emissions intensities of both passenger cars and light commercial vehicles fall by equal proportions in meeting the company’s well-to-wheel target. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Emissions intensity (gCO2e / MJ)
Carbon intensity (tCO2e / t aluminium)
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s aluminium production grows according to the global growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model Reference Technology scenario. The company has also set a company-wide target for 2025 but it could not be included in this assessment as it is unclear how it will affect emissions from the company's aluminium segment specifically. TPI has incorporated the 2030 target making the conservative assumption that the company will first exhaust non-aluminium mitigation options and will mitigate 5.2 Mt from its aluminium smelting activities (2021 Climate Change Report p.18). The 2050 net zero target has been accepted for the company’s assessment. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tCO2e / t aluminium)
column19: The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s aluminium production grows according to the global growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model Reference Technology scenario. The company has also set a company-wide target for 2025 but it could not be included in this assessment as it is unclear how it will affect emissions from the company's aluminium segment specifically. TPI has incorporated the 2030 target making the conservative assumption that the company will first exhaust non-aluminium mitigation options and will mitigate 5.2 Mt from its aluminium smelting activities (2021 Climate Change Report p.18). The 2050 net zero target has been accepted for the company’s assessment. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from aluminium production and compare the company's aluminium-specific pathway to TPI's aluminium-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company's target covers only Scope 1 and 2 emissions. The Scope 3 emissions intensity (Categories 10 and 11), which is not covered by the target, is assumed to remain constant from the latest year of disclosure. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Emissions intensity (gCO2e / MJ)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tCO2e / t aluminium)
column19: Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from aluminium production and compare the company's aluminium-specific pathway to TPI's aluminium-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company's target covers only Scope 1 and 2 emissions. The Scope 3 emissions intensity (Categories 10 and 11), which is not covered by the target, is assumed to remain constant from the latest year of disclosure. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector.  When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company's target covers only Scope 1 and 2 emissions. The Scope 3 emissions intensity (Categories 10 and 11), which is not covered by the target, is assumed to remain constant from the latest year of disclosure. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: TPI assumes that the company’s Scope 3 target applies as stated to its use of sold product emissions intensity of newly sold passenger vehicles. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (metric tonnes of CO2 per MWh electricity generation)
column19: TPI generally assesses companies based on the emissions intensity of their owned generation. However, in the case of Chubu and TEPCO, taking the emissions intensity of sold electricity (i.e. power sales) provides a more representative assessment of these two companies’ transition risk, given that it includes the emissions of JERA, an electricity utility that TEPCO and Chubu jointly own. Note that the pathway above includes JERA’s emissions and that a pathway for TEPCO’s emissions  intensity excluding JERA would be at 0.009 tCO2/MWh in 2021.  When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

Average new vehicle emissions (grams of CO2 per kilometre [WLTP])
column19: The company has set one or more targets to reduce its emissions intensity, but some of them could not be included in this assessment because they were inconsistent with TPI’s methodology. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonnes of CO2 per tonne of steel)
Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has one or more intermediate targets that cover only Scope 1 and 2 emissions, while its long-term target covers Scope 3 emissions. The emissions intensity for Scope 3 is linearly interpolated between the latest year of disclosure and the target year of the target that covers Scope 3. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Emissions intensity (gCO2e / MJ)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set a 2025 target to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. TPI has not made any further assumptions in order to project the company's 2030 and 2050 targets. The company’s Scope 3 targets are based on a fossil fuel equivalence approach  (see TPI’s Q&A document for a brief definition). When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Carbon intensity (tonne CO2e / tonne copper equivalent)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company's long-term target covers only Scope 1 and 2 emissions, while it has an intermediate target for Scope 3 emissions. The Scope 3 emissions intensity (Categories 10 and 11), which is not covered by the long-term target, is assumed to remain constant from the target year of the intermediate target that covers Scope 3. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate the company's targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that its externally sold products grow in line with the growth of the copper equivalent denominator in the National Pledges benchmark. The company's targets are understood to cover only Scope 1 and 2 emissions. The Scope 3 emissions intensity (Categories 10 and 11), which is not covered by the target, is assumed to remain constant from the latest year of disclosure. The company has an additional 2025 target that could not be included due to a lack of clarity on the base year value disclosure. Please note that this company operates in more than one sector assessed by TPI: we conduct a sector-specific assessment for each of the sectors in which a company operates. In this assessment, we evaluate only the emissions and production data from diversified mining and compare the company's mining-specific pathway to TPI's mining-specific benchmarks. Other activities undertaken by this company are assessed separately, considering only the emissions and production data from those separate activities. Targets adopted by the company that are specific to a particular activity are incorporated into TPI's appropriate sector-specific assessment. We take a case-by-case approach to the interpretation of company-wide targets to evaluate whether targets can reasonably be assumed to apply in proportion to the emissions of the activity under consideration. Investors may want to consider all sector-specific assessments of a given company to understand its overall Carbon Performance. Note that TPI does not necessarily assess every business segment of a given company. Note as well that we do not currently have a Carbon Performance methodology for the coal mining sub-sector. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column19: TPI has not made any further assumptions in order to project this company’s Carbon Performance. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column18: Emissions intensity (gCO2e / MJ)
column19: The company has not disclosed an emissions intensity that TPI can use to assess current and/or future Carbon Performance. The carbon intensity has been (re-)calculated according to TPI methodology. The company has set targets to reduce its absolute emissions. To calculate this company’s targeted emissions intensity, TPI has assumed that: The company’s externally sold energy products grow according to the regional or global primary energy supply growth rate projected in the IEA’s Energy Technology Perspectives model ‘Reference Technology’ scenario. The company’s target covers a subset of Scope 1, 2 and 3 (use of sold products) emissions. The emissions intensities of all emissions not covered by the target are assumed to remain constant from the level of the latest disclosure. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.

column19: The company has not disclosed quantitative targets to reduce its emissions, which TPI can use to estimate future carbon performance. TPI assumed that the company will continue producing zero-emissions cars. TPI’s benchmarks harmonise emissions under the EU’s Worldwide Harmonized Light Vehicles Test Procedure (WLTP). While formally adopted in September 2017, manufacturers systematically began reporting emission performance in WLTP in the reporting year 2020. We rely on conversion factors published by the ICCT to translate companies’ historical intensities from NEDC to WLTP, but previous assessments using NEDC are still accessible on our tool. When interpreting TPI Carbon Performance data, it is important to bear in mind that climate science shows temperature change is proportional to cumulative absolute CO2 emissions.
